Options.Value: Frank Wood
Luca Pacioli
Akintola Williams
William Pickles

Question 1.Question: The double entry principle of accounting was developed by
Question 1.Explanation: Lucas Pacoli propounded the double entry principle in 1494. The first book on double entry system was written by an Italian mathematician, Fra Luca Pacioli and his close friend, Leonardo da Vinci. The book was entitled as "Summa de arithmetica, geometria, proportioni et proportionalita" and was first published in Venice in 1494.

Options.Value: Entity
Realization
Conservatism
Matching

Question 2.Question: The concept that has much influence over asset valuation and income determination is
Question 2.Explanation: Matching concept stipulate that all incomes will be matched against all expenses all expenses to ascertain the net profit. Matching principle is the accounting principle that requires that the expenses incurred during a period be recorded in the same period in which the related revenues are earned.

Options.Value: Stock account and credit cash account
Stock account and credit liability account
Purchase account and credit liability account
Suspense account and cash account

Given:

.₦
Liabilities 23,700
Current assets 20,300
Fixed assets 64,500

What is the capital introduced by the proprietor?
Question 4.Explanation:
Asset = Capital + Liability

N (20,300 + 64,500) = Capital + N 23,700

N 84,800 = Capital + N 23,700

Capital = N (84,800 - 23,000)

= N61,000

Question 7.Question: Mr. Bassey purchased a motor vehicle for use in his business and debited and purchases account with the same value. This is an error
Question 7.Explanation: When many classes of account are involved in this error, such error is called an Error of Principle. An Error of Principle is an accounting mistake in which an entry violates a fundamental principle of accounting or a fundamental accounting principle established by a company.

Question 9.Question:
Use the information below to answer this question.

Five hundred naira monthly is allowed on an imprest system. The following transactions took place:

Period 1₦
Cash advanced to petty cashier 500
Petty cashier paid out: Stamp200
Newspapers 250
Period 2.
Cash to petty cashier 450
Cashier paid for writing materials350

How much should the petty cashier receive after period 2?
Question 9.Explanation:
Balance at the end of period 2 = N (500 – 200 - 250) + N (450 – 350) = N 150

Amount to receive to make it N 500 = N (500 – 150) = N350

N200
N300

Amount remained = N (500 – 200 – 250)

= N50

Question 11.Question: In a three-column cash book, the discount allowed is shown on the
Question 11.Explanation: Discount allowed are shown on the debit side in the three column cashbook. A triple column cash book or three column cashbook is one which consists of three separate columns on the debit side as well as credit side for recording cash, bank and discount. The discount column on the debit side of the cash book will record discounts allowed and that on the credit side discounts received.

Options.Value: Gross profit
Total profit
Net profit
Total revenue

Question 12.Explanation: Rent received is an income which is added to the Gross profit in the P & L a/c.

Question 13.Question:
Musa Merchant Trading and Profit and Loss Account for the year ended Dec. 31st, 2003.

.N.N
Stock (1/1/2003)60,000Sales290,000
Purchases90,000..
Cost of Goods available for sales150,000..
Stock (21/12/2003)?..
Cost of Goods Sold?..
Gross Profit180,000..
.290,000.290,000

Determine the closing stock
Question 13.Explanation:
COGS + Profit = N 290,000

COGS + 180,000 = N 290,000

COGS = N (290,000 - 100,000)

COGS = N 110,000

COGAS - Closing stock = N 110,000

N 150,000 - Closing stock = N 110,000

Closing stock = N (150,000 - 110,000)

Closing stock = N40,000

Question 15.Question:
Given:

.Jan. 2003Dec. 2003
.₦₦
Provision for bad debt 1,000.
Debtors .20,000
Bad debts to be written off.2,000

The provision for bad debt stands at 10% of debtors. How much is to be charged to profit and loss account as provision for bad debt?
Question 15.Explanation:
Debtors balance at December = N (20,000 – 2,000)

= N18,000

Provision for bad debt at December = 10% of Debtors balance = 10% of N18,000 = N 1,800

Increase in provision for bad debt from January to December = N (1,800 - 1,000)

= N800

Question 17.Question:
Use the information below to answer this question.

A piece of equipment costing N120,000 was purchased on 1/1/1996. Depreciation was provided at 20% per annum on a straight-line basis. It was sold on 30/6/1999 for N31,500.

The accumulated depreciation provision at the time of sale was
Question 17.Explanation:
Accumulated depreciation between 1996 - 1998 = 3 x (20% of N 120,000)

= 3 x N24,000

= N 72,000

Accumulated depreciation at the time of sale, which was at the middle of a year

= (20% of N120,000) x 6/12

= N12,000

Total depreciation = N (72,000 + 12,000) = N84,000
Question 17.Topic: The Final Accounts of a Sole Trader

Options.Value: N96,000
N48,000
N36,000
N24,000

Question 18.Explanation:
Net book value = N120,000 - N84,000

= N36,000

Question 23.Question: Which of the following items is found on the credit side of the sales ledger control account?
Question 23.Explanation: Bill receivable, which is an asset to the firm, is found on the credit side of the sale ledger control account. The sales ledger control account is also known as the 'trade debtors control account' and is part of the balance sheet. This account shows at any given time how much your customers owe the sole trader and the company.

Question 24.Explanation:

Capital = N 12,080

Question 25.Question:
Use the information below to answer this question.

Zazzau Company

.₦
Cash in hand 50
Cash in bank 1,250
Stock 4,880
Furniture 960
Building 5,500
Debtors 1,750
Creditors 2,150

Drawings of N125 were made by the shareholders of the company.

The capital of the company stands at
Question 25.Explanation:
Asset = Capital + Liabilities

Asset = N (50 +1,250 + 4,880 + 960 + 5,500 + 1,750)

Assets = N14,390

Liabilities = N2,150

Capital = N (14,390 - 2150)

= N 12,240

Capital = N (12,240 - 125)(i.e. Drawings)

= N 12,115

Zazzau Company

The company's net current assets amount to
Question 26.Explanation:
Net asset = Total asset - Current liabilities

= N (14,390 – 2,150)

= N 12,240

Net current asset = Current assets - Current liabilities

Current assets = N (50 + 1,250 + 4,850 + 1,750)

Current liabilities = N (2,150)

Net current Asset = N (7,930 - 2,150)

= N 5,780

Question 30.Explanation: An expense account is closed by a debit to the Profit and Loss account (which makes up the Profit and Loss Statement) and a credit to the Expense account.

Question 31.Question: The accounting convention which stipulates that money or goods taken from the business by the owner for personal use should be treated as deductions from capital is
Question 31.Explanation: Under this concept, the entity must records all transactions separately from that transaction that belongs to its owner. If it is recording, the substance of the transactions or balance should clearly be defined. For example, the owner of an entity withdraws money from the entity for use in personnel matters.

Question 32.Explanation: It is very identical to a traditional cash account in which all cash receipts are recorded on left hand (debit) side and all cash payments are recorded on right hand (credit) side in a chronological order. A single column cash book records only cash related transactions.

Use the information below to answer this question.

.₦

Canopy rent 400
Wages 1,100
Postages 300

We first calculate Cash;

Cash = Receipts – Payments

= ₦ (5,240 + 400) - ₦ (1,100 + 300 + 120)

= ₦ (5,640 - 1,520)

= ₦4,120

.₦

Cash4,120

Question 34.Question: The not-for-profit-making organizations generate their income mainly from
Question 34.Explanation: Subscriptions are dues received from the members of a club. These form part of the club's revenue. The subscription amounts are treated as revenue receipts. Subscription received from members is credited to Income and Expenditure Account on accrual basis i.e. total amount receivable from all the members as subscription should be considered as income for the year.

Options.Value: Debit side its profit and loss account
Credit side of its profit and loss account
Debit side of its income and expenditure account
Credit side of its income and expenditures

Question 35.Question: Gamji Memorial Club carried out an activity which yielded a profit of N 10,000. This amount is to be transferred to the
Question 35.Explanation: All income profit generated by the club is always credited to the income and expenditure account. The Income and Expenditure Account is a summary of all items of incomes and expenses which relate to the ongoing accounting year. It is prepared with the objective of finding out the surplus or deficit arising out of current incomes over current expenses.

Options.Value: Previous year's transaction
Daily profits
Workers performances
Management performance

Question 36.Explanation: Department accounts are prepared to aid the comparison of the management performance as well as the units the company is made up of.

Question 37.Explanation:
K = 2,000/7,000 x ₦ 21,000

K = N6,000

Question 38.Explanation: The goods transferred to branch are treated as an issue. A requisition refers to the process of formally requesting a service or item by a branch from the head office.

Question 40.Question: In reconciling the branch and head office accounts, remittance in transit in the branch books is treated
Question 40.Explanation: A "remittance in transit" is an accounting term that refers to payments that the branch has made and recorded in its accounting system, but which have not yet been cleared as received by the head office. Remittance in transit is always treated as a contra entry in the branch books.

Question 49.Question: The accounting method that reports incomes when earned and expenses when incurred is called
Question 49.Explanation: Accrual accounting recognizes income when they are earned and not necessarily received and also recognizes expenses when they are incurred and not necessarily paid for.

Question 50.Question: The tier of government that uses financial memorandum is the
Question 50.Explanation: Local government uses financial memorandum. The financial memorandum stipulates the generation and judicious management of funds for the benefit of the entire communities under a local government.
